content:
(a) No. The magnetic force is always normal to $\mathbf{B}$ (remember magnetic force $= q\mathbf{v} \quad \mathbf{B}$). It is misleading to call magnetic field lines as lines of force.
(b) Gauss's law of magnetism states that the flux of $\mathbf{B}$ through any closed surface is always zero $\int_{S} \mathbf{B} \cdot \Delta \mathbf{s} = 0$.

If monopoles existed, the right hand side would be equal to the monopole (magnetic charge) $q_{m}$ enclosed by S. [Analogous to Gauss's law of electrostatics, $\int_{S} \mathbf{B} \cdot \Delta \mathbf{s} = \mu_{0} q_{m}$ where $q_{m}$ is the (monopole) magnetic charge enclosed by S.]
summary: Explains why the magnetic force is always normal to a magnetic field line and that Gauss's law of magnetism states that the flux of the magnetic field through any closed surface is always zero.
hypothetical_questions: Why is the magnetic force always perpendicular to the magnetic field line?
What is the reason behind the flux of the magnetic field being zero?
What is Gauss's law of magnetism?
